title: Input and Basic I/O
description: Learn how to get input from users and create interactive programs

content.introduction:
So far, you've been writing programs that just display output. But real programs are interactive - they respond to user input!

In this lesson, you'll learn how to get input from users, making your programs dynamic and interactive.

### What You'll Learn
- Reading user input with `ReadLn`
- Converting input to different data types
- Creating interactive programs
- Combining input and output

concepts.title: ReadLn Function
concepts.description: ReadLn reads a line of input from the user and stores it in a variable

concepts.title: Type Conversion
concepts.description: Input is often read as strings and needs to be converted to numbers using functions like StrToInt, StrToFloat

concepts.title: Interactive Programs
concepts.description: Programs that prompt users for input and respond accordingly create engaging experiences

concepts.title: Input Validation
concepts.description: Always consider what happens if users enter unexpected input

examples.title: Simple Name Input
examples.description: Ask for the user's name and greet them personally
examples.expectedOutput:
What is your name?
[User enters: Alice]
Hello, Alice! Welcome to DWScript!

examples.title: Reading Numbers
examples.description: Read a number from the user and perform calculations
examples.expectedOutput:
Enter a number:
[User enters: 5]
The square of 5 is 25

examples.title: Multiple Inputs
examples.description: Read multiple values and use them together
examples.expectedOutput:
Simple Addition Calculator
Enter first number:
[User enters: 3.5]
Enter second number:
[User enters: 2.5]
3.5 + 2.5 = 6

examples.title: Interactive Conversation
examples.expectedOutput:
Hi! I'd like to get to know you.

What's your name?
[User enters: Bob]
How old are you, Bob?
[User enters: 25]
What's your favorite color?
[User enters: blue]

Nice to meet you, Bob!
You are 25 years old and you love blue.

exercises.title: Celsius to Fahrenheit Converter
exercises.description: Create an interactive temperature converter. Ask the user for a temperature in Celsius, then convert and display it in Fahrenheit using the formula: F = C * 9/5 + 32
hints: Declare a String variable to read input
Declare Float variables for celsius and fahrenheit
Use ReadLn to get user input
Convert the string to float using StrToFloat

exercises.title: Rectangle Area Calculator
exercises.description: Write a program that asks for the width and height of a rectangle, then calculates and displays its area (area = width * height).
hints: You need to read two numbers from the user
Read each as a String first, then convert to Float
Display the result in a friendly format

exercises.title: Personal Info Summary
exercises.description: Create a program that asks for: name, age, and favorite hobby. Then display a summary sentence combining all three pieces of information.
hints: You need String variables for name and hobby
Read age as a String, then convert to Integer
Use ReadLn three times for the three inputs
Combine all values in a final output statement

content.summary:
Excellent! You've learned:

- Using `ReadLn` to get input from users
- Converting strings to numbers with `StrToInt` and `StrToFloat`
- Creating interactive programs that respond to user input
- Combining multiple inputs in calculations and output

Your programs can now interact with users, making them much more useful and engaging!
content.nextSteps: Next, you'll learn about **control flow** - using if statements and conditions to make decisions in your programs. This will allow your programs to behave differently based on user input and other conditions!
